Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Cultural Underpinnings of Singapore Students' Good Performance in Mathematics: Implications for Mathematics Educators in the US
Award.AbstractNarration:
The United States has been bedeviled with poor mathematics performance of elementary and high school students for a long time now. This has been the concern of mathematics educators and policy-makers alike. Policy-makers and educators over the years have tried to remedy the situation by means of reforms - reforms aimed at improving pedagogy, teacher qualifications, and the curricula. Despite these reforms, the problem persists. On the contrary, Singapore's students in both elementary and high schools are performing exceedingly well in mathematics, and are ranked among the best in the world. Singapore has, therefore, become a sought-after country for advice for mathematics educators from the west, United States included. However, one area which they overlooked, and have not sought advice is the area of mathematics education culture in Singapore. This culture of teaching and learning mathematics is what this project seeks to study. Understanding the linkages between the cultural norms and the classroom behaviors of students can help inform mathematics instruction and mathematics education policy in other parts of the world, including the United States. This project will be conducted at the National Institute of Education, Singapore under the mentorship of Dr. Berinderjeet Kaur, whose primary research interest is in classroom pedagogy of mathematics teachers. The collaboration provides access to unique data that will enable new insights into students' mathematics performance.

Anthropologists generally believe that some groups do well in school because their cultures are congruent with school culture (Ogbu, 1982). This project will therefore try to learn about the cultural norms of the society and the behaviors of students. Employing ethnographic methodology, the project will seek to understand the relationships between cultural norms and classroom behaviors of students and teachers in Singapore. The classroom and after school cultures of students and their teachers will be studied, and the impact of the cultural norms on students? ability to learn and do mathematics will be explored. Classroom observations and interviews of teachers, students and their parents will be conducted using audio and video tapes. The schools for this project will be selected and participants recruited with the help of my host in Singapore.

This award, under East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

As an EAPSI-2017 awardee, I participated in the East Asia Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) program at the National Institute of Education (NIE), Nanyang Technological University (NTU) in Singapore from June 12 to August 4, 2017. My host was Dr. Berinderjeet Kaur, a professor at NIE whose primary research interest is in classroom pedagogy of mathematics teachers.

My EAPSI project on the topic “Cultural underpinnings of Singapore students’ good performance in mathematics: Implications for mathematics educators in the US” tried to delve into how the culture of Singapore, through the behavior patterns of students, teachers, and parents of students, helps her students to do well in mathematics. Singapore is the current leading performer in mathematics at the elementary and high school levels in the world according to PISA results of 2012 and 2015.

While Singapore improves in the learning and teaching of mathematics, the United States struggles with poor mathematics performance of her elementary and high school students. Reforms aimed at improving pedagogy, teacher qualifications, and the curricula were employed in the United States, but the problem persists. On the contrary, Singapore's students continue to perform exceedingly well in mathematics. Singapore is ranked among the best in the world, has become a sought-after country for advice for mathematics educators from the west. However, one area which is overlooked, and has not been explored is the culture of the people learning the mathematics. This culture, which permeates the school culture in a country, and therefore the teaching and learning of mathematics in the schools, is what this project sought to study in Singapore. Understanding the linkages between the cultural norms and the societal values on one hand and the classroom behaviors of students and teachers on the other can help inform mathematics instruction and mathematics education policy in other parts of the world.

Motivated by anthropologists’ general belief that some groups do well in school because their cultures are congruent with school culture (Ogbu, 1982) and Richard Nisbett’s (2004) argument that a person's culture and upbringing have a profound effect on how they see the world and how they process information, this project tried to learn about the cultural norms of the society and the behaviors of students. The project employed ethnographic methodology to understand the relationships between cultural norms and societal values on one hand and classroom behaviors of students and teachers in Singapore on the other. Classroom and after school cultures of students and their teachers were studied, and the impact of the cultural norms and values on students’ ability to learn and do mathematics explored. Classroom observations and interviews of teachers, students and their parents were conducted using audio and video recordings. The schools for this project were selected by convenience, and participating classes were recruited with the help of my host and the teachers involved, most of whom are volunteers. 

 Research Outcome

The outcome of my project during EAPSI-2017 can be summarized by the following research activities. By visiting the malls and other public places in Singapore, I observed how the people interact and go about their daily activities in the society, and I kept a field notebook in which I recorded things that tell the story. In the company of my EAPSI colleagues, I made trips to museums and historical places where I learned about some of the cultural norms and societal values of the people of Singapore. In the selected schools, I observed the students both outside the classroom and in the classrooms of the teachers who volunteered to be observed. Observing the classrooms, I also learned about the pedagogical strategies that the teachers employ in their teaching, especially the metacognitive strategy. Then I had the chance of interviewing 20 students, 16 teachers, and eight parents.

Analyzing my observations and interviews, it is clear that the behavior put up by students in the classroom is reflective of the culture of the society, which makes students attentive in the classroom, responsible for their success, persevering, working hard, but not asking many questions during the lesson. On the part of the teachers, they pay attention to detail, teach how to answer questions, use drills, and expect more from their students.   This outcome, I have presented with the progress of my project at the EAPSI closing ceremony in Singapore on August 4, 2017, which was attended by other EAPSI fellows, NRF research associates, and professors from NTU, including my host researcher, Dr. Berinderjeet Kaur. I hope that the scholarly connections that I made during the EAPSI project period will prove valuable as I pursue future collaborative research in Singapore.

 

Citation

Nisbett, R. (2004). The Geography of Thought: How Asians and Westerners Think Differently…and Why. The Free Press, New York. 

Ogbu, J. U. (1982). Cultural Discontinuities and Schooling. Anthropology and Education Quarterly. Vol. 13, No. 4. Pp. 290-307
